items.standfirst: Free speech demonstrations came after government said Facebook and others failed to follow new regulationsAt least 10 people have been killed in Nepal after protests over a government ban on dozens of social media platforms – including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and X – led to violent clashes with police.The government, led by the prime minister, KP Sharma Oli, has faced mounting criticism after imposing a ban on 26 prominent social media platforms and messaging apps that it says have failed to comply with new regulations. items.standfirst: Phillips, who has been on the run with his children for four years, was shot by police after officers came under fire while investigating burglary in Piopio, authorities saidA fugitive father who had been hiding in New Zealand’s rugged wilderness with his three children for nearly four years has been shot dead by police investigating an armed burglary, police said on Monday.The whereabouts of Tom Phillips has attracted headlines around the world since just before Christmas 2021, when he fled into the Waikato wilderness with his children Ember, now 9, Maverick, 10, and Jayda, 12, following a custody dispute with their mother. items.title: In rare ruling, Israeli Supreme Court says Israel deprives Palestinian prisoners of food

items.content: Israel's highest court says Palestinian prisoners are being deliberately starved in harsh prison conditions.

items.title: Palestinian prisoners not being given adequate food, Israel top court says
items.standfirst: The court said the state is legally obligated to provide enough food to ensure "a basic level of existence."
items.content: The court said the state is legally obligated to provide enough food to ensure "a basic level of existence."

items.title: Israel’s top court says government is not giving Palestinian prisoners enough food
items.standfirst: Justices rule state is legally obliged to ensure ‘basic level of existence’ and orders authorities to improve nutritionIsrael’s supreme court has ruled that the government has failed to provide Palestinian security prisoners with adequate food for basic subsistence and ordered authorities to improve their nutrition.Sunday’s decision was a rare case in which the country’s highest court ruled against the government’s conduct during the nearly two-year war. Continue reading...
items.content: Justices rule state is legally obliged to ensure ‘basic level of existence’ and orders authorities to improve nutritionIsrael’s supreme court has ruled that the government has failed to provide Palestinian security prisoners with adequate food for basic subsistence and ordered authorities to improve their nutrition.Sunday’s decision was a rare case in which the country’s highest court ruled against the government’s conduct during the nearly two-year war. Continue reading...

items.title: Alcaraz beats Sinner to win US Open title, secures world number one ranking
items.standfirst: Carlos Alcaraz defeated Jannik Sinner in four sets to win his second US Open title and reclaim the world number one ranking on Sunday. The 22-year-old Spaniard produced a dazzling display of athleticism and shot-making to overpower Sinner in their third Grand Slam final of the season.

clusters.title: Trump says ready to move on new Russia sanctions after massive attack on Ukraine
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Ready for New Russia Sanctions After Attack

items.title: Trump says ready to move on new Russia sanctions after massive attack on Ukraine
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Sunday said he was prepared to move forward on new sanctions on Moscow, hours after Russia fired its biggest-ever aerial barrage at Ukraine. Russian missiles and drones rained down across Ukraine early Sunday, killing four people and setting government offices in the capital Kyiv ablaze.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Sunday said he was prepared to move forward on new sanctions on Moscow, hours after Russia fired its biggest-ever aerial barrage at Ukraine. Russian missiles and drones rained down across Ukraine early Sunday, killing four people and setting government offices in the capital Kyiv ablaze.

items.title: Ukraine government building damaged in large Russia aerial attack
items.standfirst: Russia attacked Ukraine with 810 drones and decoys – the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, Ukraine's Air Force said.
items.content: Russia attacked Ukraine with 810 drones and decoys – the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, Ukraine's Air Force said.

items.title: Russia hits Ukraine with more that 800 drones and decoy drones in biggest-ever aerial barrage
items.standfirst: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack since the war began, killing four people across the country and damaging a key government building. Russia attacked with 810 drones and decoys, Ukraine's air force said, adding it shot down 747 drones and four missiles. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Gulliver Cragg.
items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack since the war began, killing four people across the country and damaging a key government building. Russia attacked with 810 drones and decoys, Ukraine's air force said, adding it shot down 747 drones and four missiles. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Gulliver Cragg.

items.title: Trump says he's ready to move to second stage of Russia sanctions after Moscow launches large aerial attack

items.content: Donald Trump has said he is ready to move to a second stage of sanctioning Russia, just hours after Moscow launched the largest aerial attack of the war so far.

ai_summary: Trump said he is ready to move on new Russia sanctions.
The statement followed a large aerial attack on Ukraine.
Russia launched its biggest-ever aerial barrage on Ukraine.
The attack killed four people and damaged government buildings.
Ukraine's Air Force said Russia used over 800 drones.

clusters.title: France: Bayoru government on the brink as confidence vote looms
clusters.neutral_headline: French PM Faces Confidence Vote, Possible Ouster

items.title: France: Bayoru government on the brink as confidence vote looms
items.standfirst: France's fourth prime minister in less than two years, François Bayrou, faces defeat in a confidence vote on Monday, tipping the euro zone's second-biggest economy further into political and economic paralysis. France 24's Philip Turle takes a look at what might happen next if, as expected, Bayrou's government falls.
items.content: France's fourth prime minister in less than two years, François Bayrou, faces defeat in a confidence vote on Monday, tipping the euro zone's second-biggest economy further into political and economic paralysis. France 24's Philip Turle takes a look at what might happen next if, as expected, Bayrou's government falls.

items.title: French PM François Bayrou expected to be ousted in confidence vote
items.standfirst: Opposition parties planning to remove centrist and bring down minority government after just nine monthsThe French prime minister, François Bayrou, is expected to be ousted in a confidence vote on Monday afternoon, plunging the eurozone’s second biggest economy into political crisis.Opposition parties from the left to the far right have made clear they will vote against the 74-year-old centrist, meaning he and his minority government would fall after only nine months in office. Continue reading...
items.content: Opposition parties planning to remove centrist and bring down minority government after just nine monthsThe French prime minister, François Bayrou, is expected to be ousted in a confidence vote on Monday afternoon, plunging the eurozone’s second biggest economy into political crisis.Opposition parties from the left to the far right have made clear they will vote against the 74-year-old centrist, meaning he and his minority government would fall after only nine months in office. Continue reading...

items.title: Live: French PM Bayrou fights for survival in confidence vote over austerity budget
items.standfirst: France’s parliament looks likely to remove Prime Minister François Bayrou on Monday, following only nine months in office, after the PM surprised even his own allies by calling a confidence vote to resolve a months-long deadlock over his austerity budget. Should Bayrou lose, he must resign along with his entire government, plunging France into new political turmoil. Follow FRANCE 24’s liveblog for the latest details.
items.content: France’s parliament looks likely to remove Prime Minister François Bayrou on Monday, following only nine months in office, after the PM surprised even his own allies by calling a confidence vote to resolve a months-long deadlock over his austerity budget. Should Bayrou lose, he must resign along with his entire government, plunging France into new political turmoil. Follow FRANCE 24’s liveblog for the latest details.

items.title: French PM Bayrou braces for confidence vote loss
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister François Bayrou faces a confidence vote on Monday, which he is expected to lose, plunging the euro zone's second largest economy deeper into political crisis. Details and analysis by FRANCE 24 international affairs editor, Douglas Herbert.
items.content: French Prime Minister François Bayrou faces a confidence vote on Monday, which he is expected to lose, plunging the euro zone's second largest economy deeper into political crisis. Details and analysis by FRANCE 24 international affairs editor, Douglas Herbert.

ai_summary: French Prime Minister François Bayrou faces a confidence vote.
He is expected to lose the vote and be ousted.
The vote could plunge France into a political crisis.
Opposition parties plan to vote against Bayrou.
Bayrou's government has been in power for nine months.

clusters.title: Doctor on trial in poisonings of 30 people had unique motive, prosecutors say
clusters.neutral_headline: Doctor on Trial for Poisoning Patients

items.title: Doctor on trial in poisonings of 30 people had unique motive, prosecutors say
items.standfirst: A French anesthesiologist on trial in the poisonings of 30 people, 12 of whom died, did it so he could show off his resuscitation skills and discredit co-workers, prosecutors say.
items.content: A French anesthesiologist on trial in the poisonings of 30 people, 12 of whom died, did it so he could show off his resuscitation skills and discredit co-workers, prosecutors say.

items.title: French doctor accused of poisoning patients to show off resuscitation skills goes on trial
items.standfirst: French anesthetist Frédéric Pechier, accused of poisoning 30 patients, 12 of whom died, in a twisted bid to show off his resuscitation skills, goes on trial Monday. The trial in the eastern city of Besançon follows a seven-year investigation that shocked the medical community.
items.content: French anesthetist Frédéric Pechier, accused of poisoning 30 patients, 12 of whom died, in a twisted bid to show off his resuscitation skills, goes on trial Monday. The trial in the eastern city of Besançon follows a seven-year investigation that shocked the medical community.

ai_summary: A French doctor is on trial for poisoning patients.
The doctor is accused of poisoning 30 people, 12 of whom died.
Prosecutors say the motive was to show off resuscitation skills.
The trial follows a seven-year investigation.
The doctor allegedly wanted to discredit co-workers.

items.title: Woman accused of killing her 2 kids, stuffing them in suitcases goes on trial

items.content: A trial opened in New Zealand of a South Korean woman accused of murdering her two children and leaving their bodies in suitcases for years before they were discovered.

clusters.title: Argentina's Milei suffers major setback as opposition party wins provincial vote
clusters.neutral_headline: Milei Suffers Setback in Buenos Aires Election

items.title: Argentina's Milei suffers major setback as opposition party wins provincial vote
items.standfirst: Argentina's opposition Peronist party triumphed on Sunday in legislative elections in the key province of Buenos Aires, leaving President Javier Milei's ruling party in a distant second place, the provisional official tally showed.
items.content: Argentina's opposition Peronist party triumphed on Sunday in legislative elections in the key province of Buenos Aires, leaving President Javier Milei's ruling party in a distant second place, the provisional official tally showed.

items.title: Argentina’s Milei suffers crushing setback in Buenos Aires election
items.standfirst: The Buenos Aires provincial election is a test of Milei's popularity ahead of upcoming congressional polls next month.
items.content: The Buenos Aires provincial election is a test of Milei's popularity ahead of upcoming congressional polls next month.

items.title: Argentina's Milei suffers major electoral setback as left wins Buenos Aires province
items.standfirst: Argentina’s President Javier Milei suffered a blow Sunday as his party was trounced by the left in Buenos Aires provincial elections, a contest widely viewed as a test of his government’s support. The defeat comes on the eve of mid-term polls, raising doubts over Milei’s political momentum.
items.content: Argentina’s President Javier Milei suffered a blow Sunday as his party was trounced by the left in Buenos Aires provincial elections, a contest widely viewed as a test of his government’s support. The defeat comes on the eve of mid-term polls, raising doubts over Milei’s political momentum.

ai_summary: Argentina's Milei suffered a setback in the Buenos Aires election.

clusters.title: Supertramp founding frontman Rick Davies dies at 81
clusters.neutral_headline: Supertramp founding frontman Rick Davies dies at 81

items.title: Supertramp founding frontman Rick Davies dies at 81
items.standfirst: Rick Davies, co-founder and lead singer of British rock band Supertramp, whose soulful voice and songwriting helped shape hits like “Goodbye Stranger” and “Bloody Well Right”, has died at 81 after a decade-long battle with cancer, the band announced Sunday.
items.content: Rick Davies, co-founder and lead singer of British rock band Supertramp, whose soulful voice and songwriting helped shape hits like “Goodbye Stranger” and “Bloody Well Right”, has died at 81 after a decade-long battle with cancer, the band announced Sunday.

items.title: Unite’s Sharon Graham warns Labour against diluting workers’ rights bill
items.standfirst: Union leader says employment rights bill is ‘good for the economy’ amid fears legislation could be weakenedUK politics live – latest updatesBusiness live – latest updatesUnite’s general secretary, Sharon Graham, has issued a warning to the government, saying it should enact full reforms of workers’ rights in order to fulfil a “promise to the British people”.The trade union leader said that the pledges to enhance the rights of employees were a central part of Labour’s election platform and that unions would not allow the employment rights bill to be weakened. Continue reading...

Unions will not allow the employment rights bill to be weakened.

items.standfirst: Israel flattens towers in Gaza City one by one, bombing residential buildings as it seeks to seize the city.

items.title: Watch: Israeli airstrike flattens high-rise building in Gaza City

clusters.title: Huge crowds rally for Brazil’s Bolsonaro ahead of verdict in coup trial
clusters.neutral_headline: Huge crowds rally for Brazil’s Bolsonaro ahead of verdict in coup trial

items.title: Huge crowds rally for Brazil’s Bolsonaro ahead of verdict in coup trial
items.standfirst: Thousands march in support of and against Brazil's former president ahead of Supreme Court decision on coup attempt.
items.content: Thousands march in support of and against Brazil's former president ahead of Supreme Court decision on coup attempt.

items.title: Thousands of Bolsonaro supporters rally in Brazil as coup trial verdict nears
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of supporters of Brazil’s former president Jair Bolsonaro marched on Sunday during Independence Day, protesting against the Supreme Court ahead of its verdict this week in his alleged coup trial. Waving flags and chanting, demonstrators accused the court of bias, underscoring deep political divisions in Brazil.
items.content: Tens of thousands of supporters of Brazil’s former president Jair Bolsonaro marched on Sunday during Independence Day, protesting against the Supreme Court ahead of its verdict this week in his alleged coup trial. Waving flags and chanting, demonstrators accused the court of bias, underscoring deep political divisions in Brazil.

ai_summary: Thousands rallied in support of Bolsonaro in Brazil.
Protests occurred before the Supreme Court's coup attempt decision.
Demonstrators protested against the Supreme Court's bias.
The protests highlighted deep political divisions in Brazil.

items.title: Pope Leo canonizes 'God's influencer,' the Catholic Church's first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Pope Leo XIV declared 15-year-old Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint at an open-air Mass attended by tens of thousands of people in the Vatican’s St. Peter’s Square on Sunday. NBC News’ Claudio Lavanga reports at the Vatican.
items.content: Pope Leo XIV declared 15-year-old Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint at an open-air Mass attended by tens of thousands of people in the Vatican’s St. Peter’s Square on Sunday. NBC News’ Claudio Lavanga reports at the Vatican.
